@teh_aimee @mashmatix No doubt I’m reading more into this from my own particular biases! I did enjoy the article overall!

@teh_aimee @mashmatix I don’t think the problem is that NASA staff doesn’t like to find solutions, I would guess they don’t like sifting through dozens of probably-useless solutions to find the few good ones. Again, just from my experience.

@mashmatix @teh_aimee I personally agree with the idea, but I’m pointing out the resistance this runs up against. Having tens of thousands of astroturfed comments, it can be hard for a government to handle this. In tech it’s just as hard to read source code from strangers.

@teh_aimee I worry this overlooks the real problems of open collaboration, whether it’s tech or policymaking, wrangling input from non-experts is a lot of work, and often it’s easier to just solve the problem yourself instead. More solutions do not always yield better solutions in practice.

The erosion of trust in the media is not resolved by having the public vote on what they think is truth, it's done by investing in our institutions. We have been through this before, and survived. https://t.co/prY1JecYhF
(So don't hold your breath waiting for that.)
The solution, of course, is the introduction of failure-tolerance in government at a fundamental level. This requires changes to law, politics, and culture.

Here's the thing - government can never function like a business. Business incentivized risk via profit; government is designed primarily around risk-avoidance. The resulting methodologies are fundamentally incompatible.
